trv: Caiingon Congtong Pngalan kari Lowan patis Snbrihan Seediq
english: President Tsai Ing-wen's Apology to the Indigenous Peoples on Behalf of the Government.

trv: Berih knkawas 22 saya, Senhowa ta pnrana snlmeyan kari pnsdeho " Seediq bale," sbleqan na keson " Seediq lmiqo " Dongos na pheyo ngayan nii, ssnmalo pnlawa tnsyaxan ma sproon qmita keson " Tndheran " Taiwan hini ka Seediq. Mheyo pnttowan nii, saya, mpqango ta mqori berih. Pngalan ko mdodor Lowan, mpqori ko rahor Seediq, peeyah kari yamo, psberih ko kana Seediq. Pnogolan knkawas 400 nii, mapa pnqsrnotan. Mnoda ini pntbale qnlhangan; peeyah ko kari psbrihan yamo.
english: On this day 22 years ago, the term "shanbao" (mountain people) in the Additional Articles of our Constitution was replaced with the proper name: "indigenous people." This correction not only did away with a discriminatory term, but also highlighted the status of indigenous peoples as Taiwan's "original owners." From this basis, today, we are taking another step forward. To all indigenous peoples of Taiwan: On behalf of the government, I express to you our deepest apology. For the four centuries of pain and mistreatment you have endured, I apologize to you on behalf of the government.

trv: Betaq saya snhei ko kkdosan niqol ta hini. meniq seediq mesa oxe sbrihon. Ni ka dongos mo ssberih Pngalan ko kari ka yako saya. Skrwanon mesa kiya nanaq ka ndaan cbeyo, ndaan pnqraqil nii, keson pnkrana naq ddaan seediq ka kiya keson. Ki ni ka sheyo mo hini ka saya. Pglayon mkpkriyox psdrexon pngriqan ka lnglongan so nii.
english: I know that even now, there are some around us who see no need to apologize. But that is the most important reason why I am representing the government to issue this apology today. To see what was unfair in the past as a matter of course, or to treat the pain of other ethnic peoples as an unavoidable part of human development, this is the first mindset that we, standing here today, resolve to change and overturn.

trv: Pdaane mo kari leexan moda pgkela mesa, hmowa ko lox mqori Seediq pgkari snbberih. Dheran Taiwan nii, berih 400 knkawas tena naq meniq hini ka Seediq di. Rahor Seediq meniq naq ka kkdeson daha hini. Meniq naq ka pnskari, Gaya, lleexan ma kdkilan daha. Bobo na, ini pooda kari mssrowa. Dheran nii, yahan kaalang dongal.
english: Let me put in simple terms why we are apologizing to the indigenous peoples. Four hundred years ago, there were already people living in Taiwan. These first inhabitants lived their lives and had their own languages, cultures, customs, and domains. But then, without their consent, another group of people arrived on these shores, and in the course of history, took everything from the first inhabitants who, on the land they have known most intimately, became displaced, foreign, non-mainstream, and marginalized.

trv: Pnkrana ndaan spatis rekisi ge, ndhekan naq seediq bobo na nii, wada gmrehaq mangal kana nngalan nSeediq pnoglaan nii di. Sgarang naq nleexan nniqan daha dheran hi ma, spgkaalang icil ka kkdeson daha; wada oxe tndheran ma, speeniq siyo moxi ka dheya di. Pndhekan kingal lowan Seediq, meniq ka pnheyo pnqrqanan na lowan seediq dori. Nasi ta keson oxe kingal Lowan knlangan pntlbaan, ndaan rekisi nii asi ka sproon qmita, spneero ka poso na ba bale. Kiya, sproon bale Lowan mqlahang, asi ka mbleyaq qmita ndaan nii, kndalax lnlongan troma lmngelong ddaon. Kiya ka dongos ni mo sheyo hini ka saya.
english: The success of one ethnic people can be built on the suffering of another. Unless we deny that we are a country of justice, we must face up to this history. We must tell the truth. And then, most importantly, the government must genuinely reflect on this past. This is why I stand here today.

trv: Meniq kingal patis keson " Patis ndaan Taiwan." Mgeela Pnklaan na matis mesa, " Uka pnoglaan speeniq patis ka Taiwan. Rnagoh seediq Ho, ndaan seediq Cong, snteran Cingcaw. " Spatis nii ge, knrwanan naq lnlongal na Telo. Seediq, hmrinas maxal kbekoy knkawas ka nniqaan daha ddheran nii. Stngayan naq kana ka knklaan ma, Gaya daha, pnslotoc lotoc oka msetoq. Ani si, gino naq pndaan lowan beyax pnoglekan daha ka sqita daha ka matis rekisi. Kiya ka pnogdngoson mo ka Pngalan kari, peeyah kari snberih mqori Seediq.
english: There is a book called "The General History of Taiwan" published in 1920. In its foreword are these words: "Taiwan had no history. The Dutch pioneered it, the Koxinga Kingdom built it, and the Qing Empire managed it." This is a typical Han view of history. The truth is that indigenous peoples have been here for thousands of years, with rich culture and wisdom that have been passed down through generations. But we only know to write history from the perspective of the dominant. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Dndolan Horan ma Congconkong smipaq ma gmrehaq nngalan ppyahan na Kahabo; Cingcaw knkana qnlliyan gmdara mopox. Tanahtonox, remox troma smnetor nSeediq. Betaq mhedo pncbowan, spooda pkoalang breenox na Lowan Conghowaminko. Knkwas 400 nii, knkingal keson beyax Lowan mqlahang, mangal halong mangal pnkrmoxan, gglekan ddheran. Knkana snogliqan na beyax nSeediq. Ki ni ka Pngalan ko kari, peeyah snberih mqori Seediq.
english: The Dutch and the Koxinga Kingdom massacred and exploited the Pingpu ethnic group. The Qing Empire presided over bloody confrontations and suppression. Colonial Japan put in place comprehensive savage policies. And the post- war ROC government undertook assimilation policies. For 400 years, every regime that has come to Taiwan has brutally violated the rights of indigenous peoples through armed invasion and land seizure. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Seediq ge, Gaya ka spooda smnetor kkdesan alang ma knklaan pkleexan kndkilan. Ani si, spheyo Klangan hndore, mgedang psnetor naq ddaon ma pnqlahang naq ka Seediq. Mhrehon splotolan lowan. Pnyahan beyax pngalan kari ini srwai dori. Ki ni Pngalan ko kari, peeyah kari snberih mqori Seediq.
english: Indigenous peoples maintain tribal order according to traditional customs, and ecological balance according to traditional wisdom. But in the process of modern state-building, indigenous peoples lost the right to steer their own course and govern their own affairs. The fabric of traditional societies was torn apart, and the collective rights of peoples were not recognized. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Meniq naq pnskari ka nSeediq. Mnoda pnqlahang na Tanahtonox keson oda ptholang peni. Bobo 1945 knkawas, ini prngagi pnkari daha; wada knkana ba pnsrahoq kari na ka Seediq. Knkana ka pnkari na Kahabo wada mgedang. Pndaan na knkingal Lowan mqlahang, ini bleyaq pnklawa pslotoc Gaya na Seediq. Ki ni ko Pngalan kari, peeyah kari snberih mqori Seediq.
english: Indigenous peoples had their own languages. However, with Japanese rule aiming to assimilate and turn all into imperial subjects, and with the ROC government banning tribal languages after 1945, indigenous peoples' languages suffered great losses. Most Pingpu languages have disappeared. Successive governments have been negligent in the protection of indigenous cultures. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Ciida, Lowan pqlahang, ini pklai Yameco sqada niqol daha Lani ka Hohoweriyaw. Spooda naq snliqan na Hohoweriyaw ka Seediq Lani. Ki ni Pngalan ko kari, peeyah kari snberih Yameco.
english: Without the knowledge of the Yami tribe, the government stored nuclear waste on Orchid Island. Tribe members on the island had to suffer the negative consequences. For this, I apologize to the Yami people on behalf of the government.

trv: Kndalax knrmexan Kaalang ka Taiwan, pnoglaan daha ndaan ka leexan gqiyan hido Pinpoco. Knkingal Lowan mqlahang betaq saya, psteqan ngayan nSeediq ka Pingpoco. Ki ni Pngalan ko kari, peeyah kari snberih Pingpoco.
english: Ever since outsiders began arriving in Taiwan, the Pingpu ethnic group on the western plains have born the brunt of the impact. One ruling power after another eroded the individual and collective identities of the Pingpu ethnic group. For this, I apologize to the Pingpu ethnic group on behalf of the government.

trv: Pnkriyox pooda kari lowan, cmniyok kari dndolan na Pntalang Lowan Seediq. Lowan Pnqlahang cmniyok kari. Doma ka ndaan tikoh ma meniq ka so doma kndromoc na tikoh dori. Saya, niqal snbleqan ka " Gaya poso pnsdeho Seediq," ani si, patis Horico nii, ini psroi qmita na snaaxan Lowan mqlahang. Ndaan na meniq ini kdiida, ini pkkana, ini kmmalo. Ki ni Pngalan ko kari, peeyah kari snberih Seediq.
english: After the democratic transition, the country began to respond to the appeals of indigenous movements. The government made certain promises and efforts. Today, we have an Indigenous Peoples Basic Law that is quite advanced. However, government agencies have not given sufficient weight to this law. Our actions have not been fast enough, comprehensive enough or sound enough. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Kragon mesa niqol " knklegan Gaya " ka Taiwan. Ani si, betaq saya, hei, stgesa, pyahan kkdeson, pprngagan sqlahangan. So kana knklegan sqita ge, meniq bale ka ini pntnai ka nSeediq. Mntena, knkllaan daha naq lnlongan, so ka tnsyaxan, waga naq hiya dongal. Ini dehok ndaan na ka Lowan mqlahang. Spaapa ndaan oxe knklaan doma lowan ka pnqraqil, pnsteqan lnlongan. Ki ni Pngalan ko kari, peeyah kari snberih Seediq.
english: Taiwan is known as a culturally diverse society. But even today, indicators on health, education, economic livelihood, political participation and more still show gaps between indigenous and non- indigenous peoples. Meanwhile, stereotypes and even discrimination against indigenous peoples have not gone away. The government has not done enough, so indigenous peoples have suffered pain and frustration unknown to other ethnic peoples. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Ini dehok ka ndaan nami. Pnsltolan lotoc dori, ini dheki nonaagoh qmita ka ini dehok kndromoc betaq saya. Bale ba qnnaqah bale. Pnsberih mo saya, bsiyaq ba wada msrahoq. Ani si bale ba bale ka kingal pndringan. Ini ko psmyah ndaan pnqraqil smeeliq 400 knkawas na ka Seediq. Maha pgdongos kingal pntasan, kingal kari pnsbrihan, mpsetoq ka qnnaqah. Pnsliqan mosa dehok mddahor. Ani si, kndalax ko lnlongal troma psmeyah. Pnsbrihan saya, mpgqori prdingan pkptbale ka knkingal seediq meniq Klangan hini.
english: Our efforts have fallen short, and succeeding generations have been blind to this inadequacy. Because of this, your hardship has continued to this day. For this we are truly sorry. Today's apology is long overdue, but it is a beginning. I do not expect any one speech or phrase of apology to wipe away four centuries of pain and suffering by the indigenous peoples. But I do hope with all my heart that today's apology will set this country and all its people on the path towards reconciliation.

trv: Srwai ko mangal kingal knklaan lowan nSeediq, mrengo prngagan ali saya. Kari nTayal, " Poso bale " Balay keson. " Mddahor " Sbalay keson. Prnaan S ka berih na. Poso Bale daha ka Mddahor, mgeegol ka pnyahan na. Pryoxan kari mrengo, Mddahor, asi ka peeyah lnlongan troma mqqita Poso Bale, kiya ka maha mpdehok.
english: Please allow me to shed light on this occasion with a piece of indigenous wisdom. In the Atayal language, truth is called "Balay," and reconciliation is called "Sbalay," so you simply add an "S" sound to "Balay." Truth and reconciliation are in fact two related concepts. In other words, only by facing the truth sincerely can reconciliation be attained.

trv: Gaya Seediq, meniq so snliqan nGaya Seediq alang, asi ka mddahor; msseli berih rodan. Msoopo mprengo. Ini asi ppsberih. Pprngagan daha kndalax lhebon troma ka lnlongan mgeela. Bobo na pnrngagan Poso Bale nii, spiimah sino na rodan, psetoq kari ndaan. Nii ka " Sbalay " Mddahor.
english: In indigenous cultures, when a tribe member has offended another and intends to reconcile, an elder brings together the offender and the offended - not to produce a direct apology, but to allow each side to frankly share their inner journeys. When this truth-telling concludes, the elder calls for everyone to drink together, so that what is past is truly past. This is "Sbalay."

trv: Psmyahon mo ali saya ge, Sbalay na Lowan Pngalan Kari daha ka nSeediq. Ndaan qnooqo cbeyo, Poso Bale cbeyo, spooda mo knklaan, oxe pdeqo. Uxe pkrangi mrengo. Kiya hari, dangi Seediq mprengo lnlongan na dori. Mpdeqo ko mesa yamo srwai ko. Ani si peeyah ko lhebon troma psmeyah kana namo. Uxe eroero snposan ka qnqowan. Lowan nii, mpeeniq kingal ali, mooda bale ba bale Mddahor.
english: I hope today's occasion can be a "Sbalay" between the government and the indigenous peoples. I have spoken of past mistakes and truths the best I can, with nothing held back. In a moment, our indigenous friends will speak. I do not dare ask you to forgive, here and now. But I sincerely ask you to sustain the hope that past wrongs will not be repeated, and that one day, this country can see true reconciliation.

trv: Saya ge, sprdingan ka saya.Ye maha mpdehok betaq Mddahor; pgdongos nii ge, oxe meeniq Seediq daka Pinpoco. Oda nLowan Pnngalan Kari ka nii. Mkela ko msberih, oxe wano nanaq pskari. Ndaan kana oda spooda nSeediq nii, qtaan Lowan Pngalan Kari, ye bale ba bale keson ka ni Mddahor.
english: Today is only a beginning. The duty for reconciliation lies not with the indigenous peoples and the Pingpu ethnic group, but with the government. I know that words of apology alone are not enough. What we actually do for the indigenous peoples will decide whether reconciliation succeeds or stumbles.

trv: Pgkela ko kari hini, Congtongho mpheyo " Yencominriso cowansingcongi." Yako ge, qbsoran Lowan pngalan kari mplawa. Mtooman knkingal pnngalan kari nSeediq soopo migin risocongi ma mpstena mprengo pprngagn oda ddaon na Lowan nii.
english: Therefore, I am here to announce that we are setting up an Indigenous Historical Justice and Transitional Justice Commission under the Presidential Office. As the head of state, I will serve as convener and work hand in hand with tribal representatives to pursue historical justice. We will also discuss, on the basis of equality, the future policy direction of this country.

trv: Msnposan ko mprengo, Congtonghoweyenhowe, psroon qmita ka pstnaon oda Lowan daha ka nSeediq. Knkingal pnyahan pngalan kari nSeediq ma lowan Pingpoco, Spooda pnrngagan lowan seediq daka alang. Oda nii, mpooda oda pnrngagan nYencomin ka nii. Spyahan kari pneeyah naq ba nSeediq.
english: I want to stress that this commission places the greatest importance on equality between the country and the indigenous peoples. The election of tribal representatives, including for the Pingpu ethnic group, will take as basis the consensus of peoples and tribes. This commission will serve as a mechanism for collective decision-making by indigenous peoples, and will ensure that the voices of tribe members find true expression.

trv: Meniq Dongan, mpdoron ko Singcongyen peeniq ali pprngagan " Pstotoy Gaya poso pnsdeho Seediq." Pnrngagan Weyen spooda oda Lowan knii. Mpooda pnknaan qori lowan, mprengo ooda ddaon nii. Oda nii, kana sskadi lnlongan ta rekisi, scikon pstoyan ta naq mpqlahang nanaq nYencomin. Sptena pkrana ppyahan, mpslotoc stgesa ma Gaya, spkmalo ba hei. Kana ka beyax bnege nYecomin meniq Alang breenox.
english: In addition, I will request that our Executive Yuan convene regularly the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law Promotion Committee, and use the Yuan's authority to coordinate and handle matters related to any consensus reached by the above-mentioned commission. These matters include the following: to retrieve historical memories, to promote indigenous self-government, to seek fair economic development, to ensure continuation of culture and education, to safeguard indigenous health, and to protect the rights of urban indigenous peoples, etc.

trv: Gaya pnsdeho hndore daha ka Gaya pnsltolan nrodan. Meniq ba ka ini pggalok. Mpheyo peeniq pnklaan nGaya " Sslingan horico Yencomin," smmalo leexan naq oda Yencomin. Pthowe pggalok Gaya rodan ma Gaya hndore. Pkoango ni kndodon mrana ka sqqehor.
english: Where modern laws and indigenous traditional cultures are at odds, we will set up an Indigenous Legal Service Center with a high degree of cultural sensitivity, to reduce through institutional design the growing clashes between indigenous customs and modern laws.

trv: Spdoron miyan ka snknaxan mooda ka Lowan, ptyexon smnetor ka pntleexan nYencomin. Dheran ngngalan camac oxe pnkriyox gnbaroy, mangal camac pndkaran pnkrana. Plwanon hoing, ptloongon sapah koong psqrinoc. Asi ka slngelong pprngagan ka sooda malo.
english: I will ask the relevant agencies to immediately pull together cases in which indigenous community members have been indicted or sentenced for hunting, where the hunting was done in accordance with traditional customs, on traditional lands, and for non-transactional needs, and where the animals hunted were not protected by conservation laws. For such cases we will deliberate solutions.

trv: Spdoron mo ka snknaxan ooda Lowan dori. Psnetor ndaan spoosa Lani ka howehoriyaw, speeyanh ka patis pgkela Poso Bale. Ini pdai kari mhiti bale hayan, bbleqon spririh ka Yameco.
english: I will also direct relevant agencies to present an investigative report on the decision-making process of nuclear waste storage on Orchid Island. Before finding a permanent solution for the nuclear waste, we will provide the Yami tribe appropriate compensation.

trv: Pstnaon, pooda pnklaan naq na ka Pingpoco. Psrwanon pnyahan pnkari nii dori, spooda ali 30 idas 9 pprngagon ka qori howakowe. Sbege ka pntlongan na ma pnyahan na.
english: At the same time, under the principle of respecting the Pingpu ethnic group's self- identity, and recognizing their identity, we will examine relevant laws before September 30 of this year, so that Pingpu ethnic group identity will receive the rights and status it deserves.

trv: Knkawas ali 1 idas 11 knii, prdingan miyan pgoayos, pgkela ddheran nYencomin. Spooda pnheyo naq Poro Konghowajen. Pkleelo psroon oda nYencomin " Yencomin cocohowa," "Yencominco totijihaiyihowa" ma, kana" Yencomin yiyenhowacanhowa". Shadon Rihowayen psgao prngagan.
english: On November 1 of this year, we will begin to delineate and announce indigenous traditional territories and lands. The system of tribal public corporation is already in place. In the future, the ideals of indigenous self-government will be realized step by step. We will step up the pace and submit for legislative deliberation three laws of great importance to indigenous peoples: the Indigenous Peoples Self-Government Law, the Indigenous Peoples Land and Sea Areas Law, and the Indigenous Languages Development Law.

trv: Bobo mnekan saya, mpseli miyan prngagan JenkoYencomin Sincon Howei. Pprngagan nii, ego pgklaon oda na Lowa. Bobo na knkingal knkawas ali 1 idas 8, pgkela mprengo ndaan snmalo spatis pntbale na Sinconyen. Ptteyan spheyo oda Yencomincoco. Nii ka ooda Yencomin pdhekan pntyowan ttero na Lowan.
english: Later this afternoon, we will convene a national indigenous peoples administrative meeting. In that meeting, the government will elaborate on the policies. On every August 1 to come, the Executive Yuan will report to the indigenous peoples our progress on restoring historical justice and transitional justice. To implement the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law, to serve indigenous historical justice, and to lay the foundation for indigenous self- government - these are the three major goals for the government's policy towards indigenous peoples.

trv: Mplawa ko kana ni hini, kana pggarang kari berih na terebi ma owangro. Dangi Yencomin, pspoe ta qmita ka ndaan nii. Mlawa ko kana namo mpqlahang, oxe psddilan; smbeyax, mprengo, pgpndhegan kari Lowan. Smeelo smmalo qnqowan ndaan.
english: To all of our indigenous friends here and watching on TV and online: I invite you to stand witness. I invite you not to endorse, but to oversee. Please keep pressure on the government and right its course where necessary, so that it will realize its commitments and right historical wrongs.

trv: Mhowe bala kana dangi Yecomin. Yamo pnogkela kana seediq Lowan nii. Qnqahan dheran, pnsltolan Gaya. Uka kpriyoxan ka qnbleqan; bqanon naq ka qnbleqan na nii.
english: I want to thank all of our indigenous friends. You remind everyone in this country that there is irreplaceable value in the land we tread on and the traditions we inherit. This value deserves dignity.

trv: Bobo na, Spooda ta pnstoyan oda nii, psltolan ta ltlotoc nYencomin. Kana lowan meniq dheran nii, oxe mpgedang pnskari, oxe mpgedang slngelong ndaan. Uxe sptheya Gaya pnsltolan nrodan. Uxe pqdriqor naq ndheran nii di.
english: In the future, we will push for policies to ensure that succeeding generations of indigenous tribes and all ethnic peoples in Taiwan never lose their languages and memories, that they are never separated from their cultural traditions, and that never again are they lost in a land of their own.

trv: Dmoron ko kana msoopo kndromoc pgkela ndaan rekisi. Pgkela ndheran ta, pgkela oxe pntnaan ka Gaya lowan ta. Spooda oda Mddahor, soopo moodos knkdesan pnldaxan, knbgorah Taiwan.
english: I call upon our entire society to come together and get to know our history, get to know our land, and get to know the cultures of our many ethnic peoples. Let us work towards reconciliation, a shared existence and shared prosperity, and a new future for Taiwan.

trv: Mdoron ko kana seediq Lowan, spdae ta ali saya, msoopo smmalo kingal meniq Ptbale, knklegan sptena pskingal ka Lowan ta Klangan.
english: I call upon all citizens to seize the opportunities offered by this day - to join together, work hard, and build a country of justice, a country of true diversity and equality.

trv: Patas bokong klwaan Cay Ing-Un pqori seejiq tnposo ppsrowa qnqoan
english: President Tsai Ing-wen's Apology to the Indigenous Peoples on Behalf of the Government.

trv: Emposal dha hngkawas brah na jiyax sayang, nomal poso gaya ta bnkog ska hiya ka "seejiq mqdgiyaq"o wada ryoxon"seejiq tnposo." Ptposo hangan nii o aji wana wada pkeangal pnseanak hangan, dori ni wada pteora hnigan seejiq tmposo o "seejiq tnposo" Taywang. Hyoga ta babaw poso nii qangaw ta kingal qatar brah. Paah balay lnglongan empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan pqori ko kana seejiq tnposo ppsrowa qnqoan. Qori wada spat kbkoy hngkawas, kana namo ka wada mapa qnrqilan ni ini psdkai qmita o empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan pqori ko monan ppsrowa qnqoan.
english: On this day 22 years ago, the term "shanbao" (mountain people) in the Additional Articles of our Constitution was replaced with the proper name: "indigenous people." This correction not only did away with a discriminatory term, but also highlighted the status of indigenous peoples as Taiwan's "original owners." From this basis, today, we are taking another step forward. To all indigenous peoples of Taiwan: On behalf of the government, I express to you our deepest apology. For the four centuries of pain and mistreatment you have endured, I apologize to you on behalf of the government.

trv: Snhyion mo, bitaq sayang nii mniq kgkyyig ta ka doma seejiq o ana ini psbrnahi msa. Asaw saw nii kika poso balay seiyah mo pririh Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan noda. Ngalan dha saw ida nkiya ka ana mano endaan ini psdka noda, aji ori o endaan qnrqilan klgan seejiq ni sqita dha ida asi saw nii ka skrana seejiq msa o kika poso balay shiyog mo hini sayang tgplealay balay kkmpriyox lnglongan.
english: I know that even now, there are some around us who see no need to apologize. But that is the most important reason why I am representing the government to issue this apology today. To see what was unfair in the past as a matter of course, or to treat the pain of other ethnic peoples as an unavoidable part of human development, this is the first mindset that we, standing here today, resolve to change and overturn.

trv: Jyanay mo kari msleexan, poso balay seiyah mo pgkla ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq tnposo. Dxgal Taywang nii o spat kbkoy hngkawas brah niya tna niqan seejiq ka mnniq hini da. Dseejiq nii o moda nanak kndsan dha, niqan nanak kari dha, knkla kndsan, gaya ni nniqan dha. Lmotot niya, aji mnda snrwaan dha ni wada miyah dxgal hini ka kingal qporing seejiq raaw.
english: Let me put in simple terms why we are apologizing to the indigenous peoples. Four hundred years ago, there were already people living in Taiwan. These first inhabitants lived their lives and had their own languages, cultures, customs, and domains. But then, without their consent, another group of people arrived on these shores, and in the course of history, took everything from the first inhabitants who, on the land they have known most intimately, became displaced, foreign, non-mainstream, and marginalized.

trv: Knrana endaan o mniyah babaw na ka seejiq o wada gmeelok mangal kana ana mano nseejiq tnposo. Wada pqloli tealax paah nniqan gnkla dha balay, wada maaseejiq isil, wada maaseejiq aji tmposo, wada maaseejiq mniq tgmohing. Kingal klgan seejiq wada moda son o ida bi yaa sphiyog dha babaw qnrqilan seejiq. Rahoq na ini ta pgkla, ita o kingal klwaan mnegslago, nasi aji do asi ta ka sproon balay qmita ka endaan nii, asi ka srngaw knbalay. Babaw niya, poso balay o Mklawa Klwaan ga, asi ka paah balay lnglongan psbrinah lmnglong endaan nii, kika poso balay seiyah mo mhiyog hini jiyax sayang.
english: The success of one ethnic people can be built on the suffering of another. Unless we deny that we are a country of justice, we must face up to this history. We must tell the truth. And then, most importantly, the government must genuinely reflect on this past. This is why I stand here today.

trv: Niqan ka kingal patas, hangan na o "Endaan Taywang." Kari plealay na hiya o saw nii kari na, "Taywang o ongat endaan. Seejiq Msqoring ka mnroq na, Teyseyko ka qmneepah na, Mansyo ka pnkrana na." nii ka poso balay qqita endaan seejiq Klmokan. Seejiq tnposo o tna wada piya kmxalan kbkoy hngkawas brah na mnniq hini da, niqan mttoko balay knkla kndsan dha ni wada mllotot kngkingal knxalan. Kiya ni wana paah qori qqita lnglongan tghbaraw seejiq ka ppatas ta endaan, asaw nii, pririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq tnposo.
english: There is a book called "The General History of Taiwan" published in 1920. In its foreword are these words: "Taiwan had no history. The Dutch pioneered it, the Koxinga Kingdom built it, and the Qing Empire managed it." This is a typical Han view of history. The truth is that indigenous peoples have been here for thousands of years, with rich culture and wisdom that have been passed down through generations. But we only know to write history from the perspective of the dominant. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Biyax kklawa Seejiq Msqoring ni Teyseyko ga, wada pkbaax phoqil ni rmingat mangal dnooy klgan seejiq Pipowa;klwaan Mansyo siida ori o wada mkniwa psdara ni mrot;klwaan Nihong siida o wada mtmay mkniwa kmlawa seejiq tnposo, bitaq balay babaw tnjyalan moda pklmokan seejiq tnposo ka klwaan Cyokoko. Spat kbkoy hngkawas nii o kana mnda Taywang hini ka biyax kklawa o powda biyax qngqaya tgjiyal, rmingat gmeelok dxgal ni moda embiyax balay smeeliq poso biyax seejiq tnposo. Asaw nii empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq tnposo.
english: The Dutch and the Koxinga Kingdom massacred and exploited the Pingpu ethnic group. The Qing Empire presided over bloody confrontations and suppression. Colonial Japan put in place comprehensive savage policies. And the post- war ROC government undertook assimilation policies. For 400 years, every regime that has come to Taiwan has brutally violated the rights of indigenous peoples through armed invasion and land seizure. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Seejiq tnposo o morog gaya psdrox eoda alang, dori ni dmooy kkla nrodan psbalay mneodos lnglingay. Kiya ka kiya ni endaan phiyog gaya klwaan sayang o seejiq tnposo ga, wada rmahoq powda lnglongan dha nanak ni poso biyax kklawa dha nanak. Wada sliqan ka bbkog tnlangan dha sbiyaw, ini srwani ha ka poso biyax qmpringan dha. Asaw nii empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq tnposo.
english: Indigenous peoples maintain tribal order according to traditional customs, and ecological balance according to traditional wisdom. But in the process of modern state-building, indigenous peoples lost the right to steer their own course and govern their own affairs. The fabric of traditional societies was torn apart, and the collective rights of peoples were not recognized. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Seejiq tnposo o niqan nanak kari dha, mnda klwaan Nihong wada pkNihong dhyaan, dori ni babaw maxal mngari kbkoy mspatol rima hngkawas, Mklawa Klwaan o wada dmakar prngaw kari seejiq tnposo, nii o wada paro balay pkeongat kari klgan seejiq tnposo. Wada mqhdo hari maaongat kana ka kari seejiq Pipowa. Kana mnda hini ka Mklawa Klwaan o wada ini dhoq kmbiyax kmlawa knkla kndsan nrodan seejiq tnposo, asaw nii empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq tnposo.
english: Indigenous peoples had their own languages. However, with Japanese rule aiming to assimilate and turn all into imperial subjects, and with the ROC government banning tribal languages after 1945, indigenous peoples' languages suffered great losses. Most Pingpu languages have disappeared. Successive governments have been negligent in the protection of indigenous cultures. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Hngkawas siida, Mklawa Klwaan o spowda dha ini kla ka seejiq Tao ni wada pniqon alang Tao ka Qoci Samaw Poso Biyax. Wada mangal pnqnaqih Qoci Samaw Poso Biyax ka seejiq Tao. Asaw nii empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq Tao.
english: Without the knowledge of the Yami tribe, the government stored nuclear waste on Orchid Island. Tribe members on the island had to suffer the negative consequences. For this, I apologize to the Yami people on behalf of the government.

trv: Paah mtmay Taywang hini ka seejiq pnaah isil do mnniq breenox ryaxan hidaw ka seejiq Pipowa ka wada plealay bi smtrong. Mnda hini ka mklawa klwaan o wada pkeongat hnigan seejiq Pipowa, asaw nii empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq Pipowa ori.
english: Ever since outsiders began arriving in Taiwan, the Pingpu ethnic group on the western plains have born the brunt of the impact. One ruling power after another eroded the individual and collective identities of the Pingpu ethnic group. For this, I apologize to the Pingpu ethnic group on behalf of the government.

trv: Wada kmpriyox maaposo ka seejiq do wada smiyok pneysa seejiq tnposo ka Mklawa Klwaan. Kiya ni wada psdhog ka Mklawa Klwaan ori, wada embiyax bi moda ori. Sayang do niqan mrana balay ka "poso gaya seejiq tnposo" da, kiya ka kiya ni gaya nii o wada ini sprooy Mklawa Klwaan. Noda nami o wada ini ptgeagoh, ini pqhdo, ini pttoko knmalo. asaw nii empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq tnposo.
english: After the democratic transition, the country began to respond to the appeals of indigenous movements. The government made certain promises and efforts. Today, we have an Indigenous Peoples Basic Law that is quite advanced. However, government agencies have not given sufficient weight to this law. Our actions have not been fast enough, comprehensive enough or sound enough. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Taywang o tnlangan"lala klgan knkla kndsan"son. kiya ka kiya ni bitaq sayang, seejiq tnposo ga, qori kkbiyax hiyi, ttgsa, kndsan dnooy, tteomal kklawa ni qori pnskraya lala klgan o ida gaga tgbokoy aji seejiq tnposo. Dori qori qqita seejiq tnposo o ida ini kmpriyox psnakan qmita. Ini pntoko ka qneepah Mklawa Klwaan, wada pqraqil seejiq tnposo aji endaan doma klgan seejiq. asaw nii empririh ko Mklawa Klwaan ppsrowa qnqoan qori seejiq tnposo.
english: Taiwan is known as a culturally diverse society. But even today, indicators on health, education, economic livelihood, political participation and more still show gaps between indigenous and non- indigenous peoples. Meanwhile, stereotypes and even discrimination against indigenous peoples have not gone away. The government has not done enough, so indigenous peoples have suffered pain and frustration unknown to other ethnic peoples. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

trv: Ini toko ka qneepah nami, kngkingal knxalan wada nami ini hlayi nhari ka kneini toko qneepah nami, kika wada pqraqil hiyi namo, bitaq sayang. Ini ta balay kla. Ppsrowa qnqoan sayang o ana yaa mtraraw bsiyaq balay, kiya ka kiya ni nii o pnrjingan. Ini ko solo qnrqilan spat kbkoy hngkawas o asaw kingal patas nii ni kingal kari ppsrowa qnqoan do mha msbalay da. Kiya ka kiya ni pnaah balay lnglongan mo smolo, pnsbrinah qnqoan jiyax sayang o kika pnrjingan mqori pnsbalay seejiq knlwaan nii.
english: Our efforts have fallen short, and succeeding generations have been blind to this inadequacy. Because of this, your hardship has continued to this day. For this we are truly sorry. Today's apology is long overdue, but it is a beginning. I do not expect any one speech or phrase of apology to wipe away four centuries of pain and suffering by the indigenous peoples. But I do hope with all my heart that today's apology will set this country and all its people on the path towards reconciliation.

trv: Srwai ko pdooy kingal kkla lmnglong seejiq tnposo ka miyah ko pgkla hini jiyax sayang. Kari seejiq Embgala ga, "balay endaan" o "balay" ni "psbalay"o"sbalay," kiya o psaan phnang"s" brah na ka "balay"do "sbalay" kson. balay ni sbalay nii o mndka poso kari na. ryoxon ka kari o balay bi psbalay o wana moda balay bi lnglongan mtdqras knbalay kika dhoq psbalay.
english: Please allow me to shed light on this occasion with a piece of indigenous wisdom. In the Atayal language, truth is called "Balay," and reconciliation is called "Sbalay," so you simply add an "S" sound to "Balay." Truth and reconciliation are in fact two related concepts. In other words, only by facing the truth sincerely can reconciliation be attained.

trv: Kska knkla kndsan seejiq tnposo ga, nasi niqan seejiq ka wada pqnaqih taxa alang hiya, nasi mkmpsbalay ga, rodan o pspoon na ka pnqnaqih ni wada pqnqihan. Pspoon o aji asi ppsrowa qnqoan, kiya ni pllayon pprngaw lnglongan dha. Wada mnhdo rmngaw kari lnglongan dha do pseopo peimah kingal prato sinaw ka rodan ni kika wada balay bi mnhdo ka endaan da. Nii o kika kson psbalay.
english: In indigenous cultures, when a tribe member has offended another and intends to reconcile, an elder brings together the offender and the offended - not to produce a direct apology, but to allow each side to frankly share their inner journeys. When this truth-telling concludes, the elder calls for everyone to drink together, so that what is past is truly past. This is "Sbalay."

trv: Snolo mo jiyax sayang o ppsbalay mo Mklawa Klwaan ni seejiq tnposo. Ngalon mo ka qnqoan endaan, knbalay endaan ni dooy mo kana biyax ni aj mo rangi ana kingal rrngaw mo. Lawa cicih, seejiq tnposo o emprngaw lnglongan dha ori. Ini ko ksa srwai sayang da, kiya ka kiya ni pnaah balay lnglongan mo ka ppeeniq snloan monan, qnqoan endaan do aji empnposal moda dori, klwaan nii o ida empniqan kingal jiyax, balay bi empqori msbalay.
english: I hope today's occasion can be a "Sbalay" between the government and the indigenous peoples. I have spoken of past mistakes and truths the best I can, with nothing held back. In a moment, our indigenous friends will speak. I do not dare ask you to forgive, here and now. But I sincerely ask you to sustain the hope that past wrongs will not be repeated, and that one day, this country can see true reconciliation.

trv: Pnrjingan ka jiyax sayang, qpahon moda psbalay o Mklawa Klwaan aji seejiq tnposo ni seejiq pipowa. Mkla ko, wana kari nanak ka ppsrowa qnqoan o ini toko, eoda qmeepah kana sjiqon tnposo o kika poso balay dhoq moda psbalay.
english: Today is only a beginning. The duty for reconciliation lies not with the indigenous peoples and the Pingpu ethnic group, but with the government. I know that words of apology alone are not enough. What we actually do for the indigenous peoples will decide whether reconciliation succeeds or stumbles.

trv: Empgkla ko hini, sapah qpahan thowlang o emphiyog 'qmpringan knslago endaan seejiq tnposo ni ppriyox knslago' mdooy ko hnigan thowlang klwaan ni yako ka mdodol na, seopo ko kana pririh klgan seejiq tnposo mseopo mhraw knslago endaan, dori ni seopo empprngaw qqori qpahon knlwaan.
english: Therefore, I am here to announce that we are setting up an Indigenous Historical Justice and Transitional Justice Commission under the Presidential Office. As the head of state, I will serve as convener and work hand in hand with tribal representatives to pursue historical justice. We will also discuss, on the basis of equality, the future policy direction of this country.

trv: Pskray ko rmngaw dori, qmpringan pphiyog rowan Sapah Qpahan Bokong Klwaan o nii smparo balay qmita pnegloban seejiq tnposo ni klwaan o msdka. Pneiyah pririh kngkingal klgan seejiq tnposo o mnda pnspoan empprngaw, giso balay bi pnaah hnang lnglongan seejiq na nanak.
english: I want to stress that this commission places the greatest importance on equality between the country and the indigenous peoples. The election of tribal representatives, including for the Pingpu ethnic group, will take as basis the consensus of peoples and tribes. This commission will serve as a mechanism for collective decision-making by indigenous peoples, and will ensure that the voices of tribe members find true expression.

trv: Niqan dori, emprngaw ko Poso Qpahan Klwaan ppeeniq dha jiyax eoda empprngaw"ddodog poso gaya seejiq tnposo." Pnspoan pnrngagan qpahon qmpringan o kika pspoon emprngaw qpahon Poso Qpahan Klwaan ni eoda Mklawa Klwaan babaw na. kiya o qpahon qori bbhraw aji ssngohi endaan, ddodog kklawa nanak seejiq tnposo, pplotot ttgsa ni knkla kndsan, kklawa kkbiyax hiyi ni kklawa poso biyax seejiq tnposo ga mniq alang paro saw nii.
english: In addition, I will request that our Executive Yuan convene regularly the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law Promotion Committee, and use the Yuan's authority to coordinate and handle matters related to any consensus reached by the above-mentioned commission. These matters include the following: to retrieve historical memories, to promote indigenous self-government, to seek fair economic development, to ensure continuation of culture and education, to safeguard indigenous health, and to protect the rights of urban indigenous peoples, etc.

trv: Qori knkla kndsan seejiq tnposo ni gaya sayang ga, niqan cicih ini pnlngog na, emphiyog ta niqan balay pnklwian na 'poso qpahan gaya seejiq tnposo', moda ppgaya ni tai saw psbalay giso ini pstoq pnqoqan gaya seejiq tnposo ni gaya klwaan giso spgaya sayang.
english: Where modern laws and indigenous traditional cultures are at odds, we will set up an Indigenous Legal Service Center with a high degree of cultural sensitivity, to reduce through institutional design the growing clashes between indigenous customs and modern laws.

trv: Empgspong ko Qpahan Klwaan niqan pnegloban na, nhari moda smmalo, seejiq tnposo asaw gaya ni mniq dxgal nrodan aji asaw ssmbarig mosa tmsamat ni wada pniqan rociq o qori endaan nii mowda nami empprngaw pkeongat rociq.
english: I will ask the relevant agencies to immediately pull together cases in which indigenous community members have been indicted or sentenced for hunting, where the hunting was done in accordance with traditional customs, on traditional lands, and for non-transactional needs, and where the animals hunted were not protected by conservation laws. For such cases we will deliberate solutions.

trv: Empgspong ko Qpahan Klwaan niqan pnegloban ori, qori endaan empprngaw wada speeniq alang Tao ka Qoci Samaw Poso Biyax ga, ppeiyah dha pnrngagan. Brah na ini pqhdo emprngaw ka ppeeniq Qoci Samaw Poso Biyax o niqan ka snahaw bbgay seejiq Tao.
english: I will also direct relevant agencies to present an investigative report on the decision-making process of nuclear waste storage on Orchid Island. Before finding a permanent solution for the nuclear waste, we will provide the Yami tribe appropriate compensation.

trv: Dori, qori ssparo ppgkla hyaan nanak seejiq Pipowa o qori gaya ppgkla hnigan o mngari idas mtrol jiyax brah na, mowda nami empprngaw qori gaya Tao saw meangal hnigan poso biyax dha ka seejiq Pipowa.
english: At the same time, under the principle of respecting the Pingpu ethnic group's self- identity, and recognizing their identity, we will examine relevant laws before September 30 of this year, so that Pingpu ethnic group identity will receive the rights and status it deserves.

trv: Maxal kingal idas kingal jiyax hkawas nii emprajing nami mayos, pgkla dxgal nrodan seejiq tnposo. Ppgaya qori alang o wada nami prajing moda ni babaw niya soyang snloan kklawa nanak seejiq tnposo o empknhoway maabalay. Empaa nami nhari ka giso smproon balay seejiq tnposo ka "gaya kklawa nanak seejiq tnposo;,"gaya ayos gsilong ni dxgal seejiq tnposo"ni"gaya kkrana kari seejiq tnposo"saw nii gaya o osa nhari mgay Prngagan Pphiyog Gaya ni qqita dha.
english: On November 1 of this year, we will begin to delineate and announce indigenous traditional territories and lands. The system of tribal public corporation is already in place. In the future, the ideals of indigenous self-government will be realized step by step. We will step up the pace and submit for legislative deliberation three laws of great importance to indigenous peoples: the Indigenous Peoples Self-Government Law, the Indigenous Peoples Land and Sea Areas Law, and the Indigenous Languages Development Law.

trv: Babaw kndaxan jiyax sayang, mowda nami empprngaw qpahon kana seejiq tnposo klwaan. Ska prngagan nii ga Mklawa Klwaan o mowda pgkla lala balay qpahon. Babaw niya maspat idas kingal jiyax kngkingal hngkawas o Poso Qpahan Klwaan ga, empgkla qnpahan dha kkmpriyox knslago ni knslago endaan seejiq tnposo. Pkbalay knslago endaan seejiq tnposo ni pphiyog poso kklawa nanak seejiq tnposo o kika tro dnngsan qqpahon Mklawa Klwaan qori seejiq tnposo.
english: Later this afternoon, we will convene a national indigenous peoples administrative meeting. In that meeting, the government will elaborate on the policies. On every August 1 to come, the Executive Yuan will report to the indigenous peoples our progress on restoring historical justice and transitional justice. To implement the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law, to serve indigenous historical justice, and to lay the foundation for indigenous self- government - these are the three major goals for the government's policy towards indigenous peoples.

trv: Empkagoh ko kana seejiq tnposo gaga hini, ga brah sasaw samaw, seopo ta maaseejiq empgkla. Empkeagoh ko kana namo eiyah namo kmlawa qmita, aji miyah lmkoh. Kana lopong kmbiyax dmodog, tmgsa, tai saw empkbalay ka sndhgan Mklawa Klwaan nii ni balay bi wada kmpriyox qnqoan endaan.
english: To all of our indigenous friends here and watching on TV and online: I invite you to stand witness. I invite you not to endorse, but to oversee. Please keep pressure on the government and right its course where necessary, so that it will realize its commitments and right historical wrongs.

trv: Mqaras ko balay kana seejiq tnposo lopong mo, yamo ka wada pkeiyaw kana seejiq klwaan nii, hhiyog dxgal ni kmlawa nrodan, kmpraan brihan nii o ongat rrihan. Kmpraan brihan nii o naa smproon.
english: I want to thank all of our indigenous friends. You remind everyone in this country that there is irreplaceable value in the land we tread on and the traditions we inherit. This value deserves dignity.

trv: Babaw na empowda nami ddodog qpahon, tai saw bgorah knxalan, kngkingal knxalan seejiq tnposo ni klgan seejiq nii mniq Taywang o aji mqada kari, aji empsngohi, tai saw aji empsthiyaq knkla kndsan dha nanak, aji emplotot rmigaw dxgal dha nanak.
english: In the future, we will push for policies to ensure that succeeding generations of indigenous tribes and all ethnic peoples in Taiwan never lose their languages and memories, that they are never separated from their cultural traditions, and that never again are they lost in a land of their own.

trv: Empgspong ko sseopo kmbiyax kana tnlangan, kkla ta endaan ta, kkla ta dxgal ta ni kkla ta knkla kndsan klgan seejiq ori. Pqori ta psbalay, pqori ta seopo mniq ni mrana, pqori bgorah eiyah Taywang.
english: I call upon our entire society to come together and get to know our history, get to know our land, and get to know the cultures of our many ethnic peoples. Let us work towards reconciliation, a shared existence and shared prosperity, and a new future for Taiwan.

trv: Empgspong ko seejiq klwaan, mnda saw nii jiyax sayang, seopo kmbiyax pphiyog kingal klwaan mslago. Kingl balay bi klwaan lala klgan ni msdka.
english: I call upon all citizens to seize the opportunities offered by this day - to join together, work hard, and build a country of justice, a country of true diversity and equality.

trv: Klegan keno ka fotingco na kari Nantaw Taywang?
english: What word class are negators in Formosan languages?

trv: Coti vs. Coyi na kari Nantaw Taywang
english: Topics vs. subjects in Formosan languages

trv: 4 ssaanak kntheya ka kari pstiyo na kari Mktina Takbanoaz
english: A four-way distance contrast in Takbanuaz Bunun deixis

trv: Hapyokay patis bgorah: Patis Kari Nantaw nTaywang
english: Book Launch: Handbook of Formosan Languages

trv: Qrqoron ka pnyahan /x/ kari 'Tayal ma kari Seediq
english: The mystery of Atayalic /x/: An exploration of Its origin

trv: Pnstrengan kari Drekay daha ka kari Nantaw Taywang tghonac icil
english: Language contact between Rukai and other southern Taiwan Austronesian languages

trv: Rekisi pnsterong kari Pinayoanan daha ka kari Pinoyomayan
english: The history of language contact between Paiwan and Puyuma

trv: Ptkryaxon dnpooyas smriyox ka kari pnsqapah berah kari Mktina Takitodoh: spooda qnrqoran yiryawko
english: Prosodic realization of enclitics in Takituduh Bunun: A corpus study

trv: Pnseengan hengak chedil kari Pinayoanan na alang Pioma
english: Piuma Paiwan stress in directional evaluation

trv: Bnrahan smalo ka tg3 hengak bobo snpegan peeyah bokoy Proto-Atayal
Bnrahan smalo ka hengak laqi tgbokoy *-ʔ, *-h, ma *-∅ Proto-Aostronesian
english: The reconstruction of Proto-Austronesian final *-ʔ, *-h, and *-∅

trv: Hyozyonka qori kari 'Tayal ma kari Seediq ga ddaon knbbrihan kari
english: Standardization in times of language attrition among Atayalic communities

trv: "Coko" kari Pinayoanan daha ka Relativized Minimality

english: Cliticization of oblique case marker in Sakizaya

trv: mhm eniqan kingan ah rodan ha.
maano di mhada ciida hei na qhoni.
yaani kelaan na qotirodox ori ah so hari so hari qotirodox qitaan te kelaan so mhm nasi ori ini kelai.
english: probably it is guava or pear.

trv: tkhako mosa lmamo ka rodan nii.
english: the old man goes up ladder and he picks fruits.

trv: ma paro ka paro ka ah qhoni kii bobo na qhoni ha.
ma lmamo lmamo ka ima di rodan nii.
english: the old man is picking fruits.

trv: ma i oxe beyo daha daha rawa ka lnmwan na hei qhoni ciida.
english: then when he picks two baskets of fruits

trv: ma moda hii ka kingan na riso rodan hari.
ma wada tmolos tmolos ma moda s moda toma mhm baki ga lmamo hei qhoni nii.
english: then carrying the sheep, he passed under the tree that the old man is picking fruits.

trv: kika wada moda elo wa wada hmrinas ma wada moda elo na kika REDosaon na ma qmlahang miric ah REDosaon na qmlahang miric osaon na tmabo miric peni.
english: he passes, go toward the place where he raises sheep.

trv: ma ini qbsiyaq eniqan kingan laqi.
english: in a short while, there is a child.

trv: eh s taapa rolo ha rolo ge jidensha ha.
english: he is riding a rulu. Rulu is a bike.

trv: taapa jidensha laqi q laqi nii ma wiso oN moda toma ino di.
english: the child is riding bike and he comes under...

trv: eh moda mi mo mosa qitaan na ga lmamo hei qhoni ka ba kingan rodan kiya ma mo mosa ah qitaan na ye mesa lmamo hei qhoni ma ga waga baro ka rodan kii.
english: he saw the old man is picking fruits above.

trv: kiya ka ciida de wada laqi nii.
english: thus at that time, the child left.

trv: qitaan na ka rodan kiya lmamo baro hii ma.
english: he saw the old man, picking fruits up there.

trv: ma kika i mesa ka ini ado ga maano di ini kela ali lmamo ciida ka rodan nii ha ma im.
english: at that time, the old man is picking fruits very hard

trv: ye mesa ini ko naq ini na qitai ka laqi nii ciida we.
english: he did not even know the child was looking.

trv: wada gmolos mangan kingan maano di kingan rawa na hei qhoni kii.
english: he stole one basket of fruits.

trv: so hari ah qotirodox qitaan ha.
ma qmita seediq kii qmit qmita qmita rodan di ma.
english: then he sees the old man

trv: ye mesa ka t ini ini howa ini qita ma.
english: probably he is saying that 'it is okay, he is not seeing'.

trv: wada na groos madis grooson na madis ciida ma.
english: at that time he stole and carried the basket.

trv: ni groosan na madis ye na eh ye na adison ino ini kelai ye na baroyon ye na ini kelai.
english: the fruit he stealthily took away, I wonder where he brings or whether he sells.

trv: wada moda elo ciida k moda elo ciida ini dehok sapah dong we sterong kingan laqi mqedin.
english: when he is on the way, before arriving at his house, he met a girl.

trv: laqi mqedin ori gndoanr taapa densha ori.
english: the girl also is riding a bike.

trv: taapa densha ciida laqi nii laqi mqedin nii we.
english: at that time the girl was riding bike.

trv: a ani qmita mo laqi mqedin nii ka ka laqi ah laqi rseno nii ma.
english: the boy sees the girl and then

trv: kika ini na kelai eniqan btonox ka elo ma ptebok btonox ka maano di jidensha na di ma takon ka laqi nii.
english: So, he did not know that there was a stone in the road, the bike bumped into the stone, then the child fell.

trv: takon ciida de cowaq ka maano di den ah hei qhoni lnowan na.
english: he fell down and then the fruit spilled.

trv: ma bonoh na ori we wada wada odaan tmaos na laqi mqedin ma tqada so theya hari.
english: the hat also went away. The girl touched it and it leaped far away.

trv: lo hei qhoni lonam eh gnroosan na madis kingan rawa ge tqada theya qori icin ka kiya.

trv: ma kika takon laqi nii ma mangan tikoh loqah.
english: because the child fell, he got a little hurt.

trv: ma kika qmita loqah na ga sdara peni.
english: So, he is looking at the scar to see if it is bleeding.

trv: ma wiso ka tero lx tero laqi dong.
kika tero ris tero laqi laq ah tero laqi ah.
laqi r ah rseno nii ah qmita wa takon ka ima di ah gono gnoros mangan ah hei qhoni laqi mhm mhm laqi mnangan hei qhoni nii ciida ma.
english: they saw the child who stealthily took fruits fell down.

trv: ma rireh so dmayo mesa eh mhm.
ma kika mhedo dmayo ciida de ma adison na di.
english: then after they finished, he carried the basket.

trv: ma kika wada lqlaqi wada naq tero nii maha theyaq laqi tero nii ini p.
english: then children left, the three children left to go to play.
but he does not ride bike.

trv: i ma ye ado monang loqah laqi nii ma ini ye ani ini kbeyax maano di ye na ini kmekoli qnleqah densha na di ma.
english: then maybe the child got hurt, he probably has no power to do to pedal the bike

trv: mkkesa ma toloson na ka zidensya na nii ma kana gono gnoros na madis kingan rawa maano di hei qhoni nii wa ma kika.
english: he is pulling the bike while waking, stealthily bringing the basket of fruits.

trv: wo mkkesa tikoh ma qmita bokoy.
english: he walked a little and looked back.

trv: ma qm qm mhm ah qmita tero laqi laqi wada dnayo heya di.
english: he sees the three children who helped him.

trv: ma tero na laqi deheya heya nii we eniqan kiya kingan.
english: the three children, they have one...

trv: kiya m maano di ah mqqita ma ciida ma kika ini ma mesa o ye mesa na heya ka bonoh nii ma kika hadocon na.
english: they looked at each other, and they said this is his hat, so one of them sent it back.

trv: hadocon na hadocon na laqi nii ka bonoh nii ciida de kika laqi mntakon gnroos mangan hei qhoni ge angalon na ka tero hei qhoni di ma begeon na riso dnayo na deheya.
english: when he gave the hat back, the child who fell and stole fruits took three fruits and gave them, to the boy who helped him.

trv: ma wada pnkingan mekan nii mg mekan mekan di.
english: each one left eating the fruit.

trv: de deheya tero nii ma moda kika ah ga na maano di kika rodan ga lmamo a hei qhoni kiya.
english: the three of them came to the place the old man is picking fruits.

trv: mo kndowa naq moda hii elo na dongon ma.
english: they passes the road as usual.

trv: eh ho mhm boto ah wa mosa lmamo baro ssoni han wada na geegoyan na laqi nii ciida wa.
english: he went up to pick fruits when the child stole the fruit earlier.

trv: ma kika rodan ciida de kika meyah ah toting dheran ma meyah mita maano di lnamo na hei qhoni.
english: so when he comes down, he sees the fruits he picked.

trv: hi lngelong we malo so hari daha a rawa ah l lnamo mo soni malox ka m msngari kingan bale so hari mesa ga.
english: "I have just picked two baskets of fruits. Why there left only one," he says.

trv: so hari wgag ini na kelai lmngelong.
oiwa mesa wada ino kingan ka mesa lmngelong peni na.
english: he thinks where one basket is gone.

trv: wiso ka deheya tero nii mkkesa moda hii ma mekan mekan hei qhoni kika qowaq na ma kika.
english: the three children passed there. They were eating the fruit.

trv: ma lmngelong ah baki nii mesa ye ye we ma mhowa mesa lmngelong ori ini mo kelai.
english: so the old man probably thinks

trv: ma ini na kesai ye namo oxe gneegoyan ori ma.
english: but he did not say 'did you steal?' then

trv: ini na kesai eh ini na slingi ka riso nii ma wada naq theyaq ka tero riso nii.
english: he did not ask to the young men and they went to play.

trv: a mqedin mesa rodan cbeyo wa asi ka jyonansay sa patisan sa.
english: It is said that our ancestors cannot get their faces tattooed until their are at least teenage.

trv: patison daha a a dqeras malox patisan so.
english: Why do they tattoo their faces?

trv: a mtbeno klaali qitaan dqeras daha si.
english: It is said that after getting their faces tatooed their faces look plump every day.
What do they use to powder their faces?

trv: dqeras ka ga n bagah heno so.

english: It is said that is ashes of burned charcoal of pine.
(which is used to) power the face

trv: kiya mqrehaq kii de so troma si ma.
english: (As for tattooing their face,) ashes of burned charcoal should go into their faces.
After the scab falls off, [it would look] good.

trv: ma meniq ka ropon si o.
english: And as for another custom, extracting teeth

trv: kirei qitaan ka ropon ori o angalan waqi mesa ka rodan cbeyo.
english: Our ancestors said that we look beautiful after we extract our canine teeth.

trv: a so oh kiya naq da.

english: In the past, there was no medicine. There was no doctor.

trv: loqah ge asi ka sdngedang qsiya kiya iyo na.
english: When got hurt, we immediately boiled water and that was the medicine.

trv: nasinak kntteon so dmngedang qsiya di ge.
malo nak so nexan di ini nak ini kmalo dmodon nak paro ka loqah.
english: It will heal soon. The one that does not heal will not heal. The wound would become more and more serious itself.

trv: so kiya ka cbeyo oka ising.
english: In the past, there was no doctor, so people acted this way.

trv: kika saya di ge malo di.
ano ka loqah di ge ricohan iyo de malo.
english: If you are wounded, you simply apply medicine.

trv: cbeyo ge oka iyo oka ising ma dmodon paro ka loqah.
english: There was neither medicine nor doctor in the past. The wound got worse.

trv: ma sapohan dori de asi ka eniqan ka loqah a meyah nanaq ori ge m m asi ka sapohon malo di.
english: If a skin ulcer was developed, we must turn to sorcery in order to cure it.
There was no medicine to apply.
That was the situation in the past.

trv: mqraqin riyong ka ndaan cbeyo oka iyo ma oka ising.
english: Because there was neither medicine nor doctor in the past, the procedure was painstaking.

trv: sm skadi nak so so ka rricoh daha skadi sodo sricoh daha ori so kiya.
english: They would also look for herbs for application to apply (to the wound). Like that.

trv: saya di ge malo eniqan iyo ma.
english: Nowadays, the situations are better since there is medicine.

trv: mekan iyo ising de malo ka loqah.
english: Eat the medicine prescribed by the doctor, and the wound will heal.
The procedure in the past was like that.

trv: kiya da ma kika ani maano ka ndaan cbeyo ge naqah riyong oka ising.
english: Anyway, in the past, it was unfortunate that there was no doctor.

trv: kiya nii howa mesa ori ini kelai mnarox ori ge asi ka sapohon malo.
english: So it was unknown what that would come to be. If one was sick, it was better that he received the treatment of sorcery.

trv: ini nak kmalo de mgedang kiya di.
english: He would die if he did not recover.

trv: so kiya ka ndaan miyan cbeyo yami.
english: That was our situation in the past.

trv: ini knt so kiya ndaan cbeyo nanaq.
english: It was simply like that in the past.

trv: ini ko skela riyong yako ori mbahang ko peni mbahang ko kari a rodan.
english: I did not catch up on all (the old days). I also heard some from the elderly.

trv: meniq yami ge ini ko kela ka ndaan cbeyo di.
english: We who live today do not know about the situation in the past.

trv: wana nak ka heno ka kelaon ano nak kii.
english: What I know is only that.

trv: oxe cbeyo a ita wa meepah meepah ta klaali kesao ta ho.
english: No...we worked in the past. Let's tell him we used to work every day.

trv: X cbeyo a meepah ta klaali ita na a ini ta gdoro ma.
english: In the past, we worked every day, and we did not take a rest.

trv: e meyah ta sapah dongan mtaho ta poniq.
english: We came home and we made fire.

trv: pore ta oyo pore ta ido t a trima ta laqi.
english: And then we boil water and cooked rice. We bathed the children.

trv: na on ma kika laqi ma taqi ta kika oqolon ido laqi han ma kika taqi bobo na.
english: Yes, children went to sleep, and before that we fed children first. Then children slept.

trv: so kiya ka korosi so kiya a so kiya ka ndaan nami cbeyo.
english: It was like that hard. That was our experience in the past.

trv: kiya a heno han robo mssbarox ta klaali han ma.
english: We often exchanged labors in the past.

trv: on kiya kiya a msbarox ta klaali qnborong kosoy han.
english: We often sheared lemon grass in return.

trv: on a mosa ta kn a kika smbarox hbaro seediq qnborong kosoy ma.
english: Many people helped each other shear lemon grass.

trv: akedo bale a ma ta dekiro ciida robo ha kteeto a.
english: Robo, how could we do that at that time?

trv: on kiya han mkesa ini taapa rolo ori naqah elo dori ma.
english: We walked on slopes. We could not take a car, and the road was lousy.

trv: a ma oxe bale kangtang kiya di a.
oka ta koco dori cbeyo a.
english: There were no shoes in the past, either

trv: mosa a meepah na hadasi hadasi na hadasi dori.

english: That was even farther in the past.

trv: on ma wano kosoy tikoh a heno han bobo na de kika mhoma ta kesaba di ma.
english: Only lemon grass was a little..., so we grew cassavas afterwards.

trv: on kesaba ohin ta tikoh cikao laqi de i bale ba kesaba ninenkang na.
english: We worked as hard as possible so as to earn children's allowance. We could only harvest cassavas once in two years.

trv: wada ta karion icineng bale di na.
english: We really had no money. To let children study at school, we dug (the cassavas) in only one year.

trv: mosa ta om korosi kmari kesaba na.
on a mohin ta han oka ta naq a on km maemotte ta kmbarox han dori ma.
english: We made effort. We didn't have and we borrowed it in advance.

trv: wa ta hmowa soko ciida ha.
english: How could we live that way at that time?

trv: lngelongon mo dori we ini asi maano cbeyo dori msbarox ta ma lngelongon saya.
ini ko maano maano di ini kela ini kela mekan siyang na cbeyo.
english: We could not buy pork in the past.

trv: koromane na ini ta bari siyang.
english: We did not buy pork before.
Tumun said we were like fermented soy beans.

trv: dqeras gaga kelaon mo ini ekan siyang si tomon baisorin ado kmokan heya na.
english: Tumun, who was from Baisurin, said, "I know who does not eat pork," because he was Southern Min.

trv: a msresong dqeras hari hayan ini ekan siyang di.
english: If you don't eat pork, the face will be shriveled.

trv: a a on bale ba ini ekan siyang han.
english: That's true. The faces of those who did not eat pork were dry.

trv: ini kela mari siyang cbeyo maano kana ke.
english: We did not know to buy pork.

trv: kiya ka kiya ka X kerong tikoh han haan psbego dori ma.
english: We could only cook soup with chayote.

trv: sama bale sama bale maano qcorox mremon ma qcorox mremon psbego na.
english: We used wild lettuce and salty fish to cook soup.

trv: kii kesaon mako a anaq so kiya mbeyax ta riyong peni robo ani ini ekan abora na.
english: I think, Robo, although we did not eat oil, we were still strong.

trv: ini ma oka ka oka ta mesa imahe ta sino bbiyan dori ciida on oka oka mimah sino.
english: At that time, there was not anybody among us who said in the evening, "Let's drink wine!"

trv: bbiyan kiya ka mimah ipong dongan ptalang dara na mbeyah meepah si.
english: In the evening, we drink one bottle again saying that this circulates the blood.

trv: on kiya kiya dongos na ho ima naq mkela.
english: Is that the purpose? Who knows.

trv: kiya kiya ka dongos na han.
english: That is the purpose of this thing.

trv: mama jiang yici dakis so dakis so sa.
dakis mo m dakis mo thei kari.
english: My Dakis listens to my words.

trv: malo riyong malo riyong malo riyong ciida ciida biciq ciida na biciq ciida na dooyong mo cori na mholis riyong.
english: When he was little, I grabbed his penis, and he was laughing happily.

trv: m ma mesa kingan kari a bnhangan mo ino ima di rdrodan a alang ta hiya ha.
english: Here is a story that I heard from the elders of our tribe.

trv: ani naq oxe oxe wano bale a alang ta globan ha kana alang nakahara ma alang tongan peni.
english: not only in our Gluban tribe, but also in Nakahara and Tongan.

trv: neton ta so mhoqin na hei ta wada mhoqin w wano hei ta wada mhoqin kiya mesa.
english: If we die, only our body dies.

trv: ma eniqan kesaon otox ta na ini qho an ani dehok knowan we ini qhoqin kiya.
english: What we call "Utux," whenever it is, does not die.

trv: ma ma mhoqin ka hei ta ciida di na mosa naq ino di skadi otox ta rodan ta cbeyo ma mosa msoopo hiya mesa kari daha.
english: They say, when our body dies, we go to find our ancestor's soul and then stay together there.

trv: m lmngelong ko ciida na kesaon mo ka rodan.
english: I thought about the story at that time, and said to the elderly people.

trv: dm ciida wa rodan tmgesa yako ciida mbahang ko ciida we.
english: At that time, I heard the elderly taught me.

trv: sa kchayaon mo cmiyok smiling ka rodan ciida.
english: I asked a question in reply to the elderly like this.

trv: ma mesa ka rodan oxe oxe oxe qnbahangan a kyokay nii.
english: The elderly said, 'This is not heard from the church.'

trv: kari ta naq ba rodan ba pe peeyah peyah cbeyo nii kesaon ko na.
english: They told me our own story really comes from our ancestors.

trv: kika bsiyaq ko hari lmngelong kari nii ma kika.
english: Therefore I thought about this story for quite a while.

trv: e ita kesaon seediq na neton ta mgedang peni mhoqin ta wa m kika asi ta moda moda hako otox.
english: We Seediq, if we die, we must go through the soul bridge.

trv: kesaon otox ta peni na asi ka moda hako otox.
english: Our so-called soul must go through the soul bridge.

trv: mooda ta hako otox ciida na asi ta moda pqita baga.
english: When we pass the soul bridge, we must have hands examined.

trv: n eniqan naq ka rodan ta ga a maano di mqita baga ga hiya sa.
english: There will naturally be our ancestors examining hands.

trv: rseno anaq anaq rseno anaq mqedin na mntena kana a m kogahon na baga so.
english: Man and woman are all equal. He opens your hands.

trv: e ta qitae ta baga so kesaon so na asi so naq pqitaan kana daha baga wa oxe wano kingan.
english: "Let's see your hands," he tells tou. You must let him see both your hands, instead of only one.

trv: qmita ka a maano di qapan baga ta.
ani si neton baga so na ini pgdara di na oxe so pdehok sipo sa.
english: However, if your hands are not blood-stained, you cannot reach the other side.

trv: moda so toting cceka di na mkkesa so na mlgelo paro ka hako dehok si.
english: When you walk halfway, the bridge will shake violently.

trv: kika mtoting so maano di mtoting so roro troma kii deno mesa.
english: So you will fall down into the deep stream gorge.

trv: ma kika eniqan kesaon daha a otox karang paro ga mtara hii sa.
english: There is a big what they call "crab spirit" waiting there.

trv: kiya ka meekan seediq a maano di mntoting hiya mesa.
english: will eat people who fall down there.

trv: ma dongos na nii peni na kesaon seediq mgdara baga nii peni rseno ge asi ka seediq mnangan tonox.
english: The meaning of this is, of the people with blood-stained hands, men must be those who have hunted heads.

trv: kesaon mangan tonox nii cbeyo na qmlahang kmdakan alang ka kiya.
english: In the past, the so-called head-hunting was to protect the tribe.
It was like that in the past.

trv: so mngoangan tonox han ma asi ta naq kmciyok.
english: We hunt each other's head, so we ourselves must resist.

trv: so rseno na asi ka mnangan tonox pais na kiya si patison ta na patis a dqeras.
english: Like men must have hunted enemy's heads, so that we can be tattooed on the face.

trv: ma kika m m howa ka patis dqeras nii ge pnqitaan na meniq ta bobo dheran ka kiya.
english: This face tattoo is to let other people see when we are in the world.

trv: kingan oxe seediq ani ta naq meniq bobo dheran na kingan oxe ta qqitaan we.
english: There is one thing that we people cannot see when living in the world.

trv: rseno na mnangan tonox na mgdara baga na.
english: Men who have hunted heads have blood stain on the hands.

trv: ani naq ga patisan dqeras na ge kingan naq kiya.
english: Although they are tattooed on the face, that is another story.

trv: mqedin ori na mntena naq ori.
mqedin we oxe mosa mangan tonox ka mqedin di.
m kesaon mqedin ta ita seediq na asi ka mdromoc bale maano di meepah.
english: Our Seediq women must work diligently.

trv: kesaon meepah nii we bale ba cbeyo na tminon.
english: In the past, this work was really weaving.

trv: asi ka mkela ba tminon mqedin we kii si patisan daha dqeras.
english: Women must know weaving really well so they can be tattooed on the face.

trv: ma kesaon mqedin ita seediq na be peeyah naq yani bale yani slaqi wa yani bale ye dehok so em mpito hari knkawas daha di na smlohe tminon di deheya betaq rodan ini qita doriq daha domo dmaos peni.
english: Our Seediq woman, perhaps since they are little...perhaps when they are seven or so, they begin to learn weaving, until they are so old that they can not see and pull threads.

trv: a dehok so kiya de malix tminon ka.
english: do not stop weaving until then.

trv: kesaon mqedin ita seediq kika so kndesan daha mqedin ita seediq nii na so so nii ka qnbsiyaq a non nanaq eniqon daha bobo dheran hini peni na kn wano ba tminon tminon klaali ka deheya.
english: Our Seediq women, their life is this long...they live in this world. Weaving and weaving is really what they do every day.

trv: kika baga daha ori na bale ba ego a rih so ego riyong korang.
english: Therefore, on their hands are really many calluses

trv: qtehon korang daha peni saadox korang daha korang daha baga wa.
english: Their calluses are fat...their calluses on the hands are still.

trv: ma ma kesaon korang baga nii ori na ado so dmoi kesaon korang baga nii ori na ado so dmoi gikos klaali mesa a tminon han na kong kong mesa peni na.
english: There are these calluses on the hands because you grip the loom to weave every day, "kong, kong" like this.

trv: mntena rseno ori mgdara baga mqedin dori.
english: Women's hands are also blood-stained just like men's.

trv: mntena rseno daka mqedin pqitata baga di na.
english: Man and woman are qual. have hands examined.

trv: ima si mgdara de irih so heya ka bale ba km km moodos meniq bobo dheran han na kmdakan kmdakan a qori alang ta.
english: Whoever are blood-stained, they have really protected our tribe when living in the world.

trv: ni nii ge ini pntena kesaon kari ta hndore osaon ta mbahang kyokay ha.
english: This is different from what we hear in the church recently.

trv: a eniqan a eniqan tenggoko eniqan jogoko mesa peni.
english: say there are heaven and hell.

trv: ado ko ka ga mangan kari otox baro ka yako ori ori peni na kika lmngelong ko we ma so hari mntena mesa ko lmngelong.
english: Because I also believe in Jesus, I wonder how they are similar.

trv: e bale ba bale ba ge yaani eniqan tikoh ini na pntena ori.
english: In fact, there are something which is not the same.

trv: dehok hini kari mo ha kiya.
english: My word ends here. That is it.

trv: laqi nii keeman di ma gaga tloong gakac na m.
english: It was night already, and the kid was sitting on his chair.

trv: a la kana a siyo a? taqian na qlapo na ma gaga a qmita holing nii a wa theyaq holing qmita kana ano ka ano ka qpaton.
english: was next to his bed in his room, watching his dog playing, and looking at a frog.

trv: a mrebo di ma ga m totoi ka laqi nii di.
english: In the morning, the kid got up from bed.

trv: ei ei waga mtaqi di w keeman di ma ga mosa a taqi qlapo taqian na ka laqi nii.
english: Well, no, that's not right. He is still sleeping. At night, this kid goes to sleep on the bed in his room.

trv: ma waga naq a a hiya ka ano ka asi holing ori o siyo na om soopo taqi ga meniq a? qpaton nii ori waga nanaq ptaqion so a heno ano ka a so kiya na hiya.
english: There, the dog is also beside him, sleeping together. The frog is also there, sleeping by itself. It's just like that.

trv: ma kiya ka mgrebo di na waga a totoi ka laqi nii di ma dahaka holing na.
english: In the morning, the kid and his dog get up.

trv: waga mqiri so bais so ngangoc ma mqiri so ano ka ano ka a dheran na.
english: They are looking towards the window, looking at the view outside.

trv: ma kiya ka kiya ka bobona dong waga ano ka mosa mqir mqiri kndalax bais ka laqi nii dahaka holing nii a mos oh a mosa mqiri ngangoc di.
english: Afterwards, the kid and the dog poke their heads out of the window.

trv: ma kiya laqi nii ga naq mqiri kndalax ngangoc waga mita holing na waga mosa tmalang ngangoc.
english: The kid was looking outward from the window, and the dog ran to the outside.

trv: oh mosa a so dmidin a m maano di a o mosa t tom waga so eniqan kana qhoni ma so sodo ga mosa so tmalang waga mosa theyaq ngangoc ka holing.
english: They went to bring, wait, what? There were trees and grass, and the dog ran to go play out there.

trv: kika waga na osaan ano ka ano ka ano ka memox ka holing na nii di waga na lexo wa na emoxon memox wa na theyaqan ngangoc hii kika wa mosa a mkkesa so oyong a sapah na.
english: went out to hug his dog, playing and chasing each other to the back of the house.

trv: kika wa mosa so oyong sapah na di ma waga so a mlawa ka laqi nii ma wa m waga naq lmeon mlawa ka holing nii dori.
english: As they go to the back of the house, the kid starts calling out, and the dog is also barking to call out.

trv: ma kika laqi nii dahaka a ano ka holing nii de o mosa betaq so a poso qhoni di ma.
english: So the kid and the dog went to the root of the tree.

trv: gaga mosa mita ano ka so rodo a walo ka wada a waga mosa skiya ka walo di.
